heading: Deaths
txt: Angelos Sikelianos, Greek poet and playwright (b. 1884)

entities.title: Angelos Sikelianos
entities.description: Angelos Sikelianos was a Greek lyric poet and playwright. His themes include Greek history, religious symbolism as well as universal harmony in poems such as The Moonstruck, Prologue to Life, Mother of God, and Delphic Utterance. His plays include Sibylla, Daedalus in Crete, Christ in Rome, The Death of Digenis, The Dithyramb of the Rose and Asklepius. Although occasionally his grandiloquence blun

heading: Deaths
txt: Ethel Rosenberg, American spy (b. 1915)

entities.title: Ethel Rosenberg
entities.description: Julius Rosenberg and Ethel Rosenberg were American citizens who were convicted of spying on behalf of the Soviet Union. The couple were accused of providing top-secret information about radar, sonar, jet propulsion engines and valuable nuclear weapon designs. Convicted of espionage in 1951, they were executed by the federal government of the United States in 1953 in the Sing Sing correctional faci

heading: Deaths
txt: Julius Rosenberg, American spy (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas J. Watson, American businessman (b. 1874)

entities.title: Thomas J. Watson
entities.description: Thomas John Watson Sr. was an American businessman. He served as the chairman and CEO of International Business Machines (IBM). He oversaw the company's growth into an international force from 1914 to 1956. Watson developed IBM's management style and corporate culture from John Henry Patterson's training at NCR. He turned the company into a highly-effective selling organization, based largely on p

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Borzage, American film director and actor (b. 1894)

entities.title: Frank Borzage
entities.description: Frank Borzage was an Academy Award-winning American film director and actor, known for directing 7th Heaven (1927), Street Angel (1928), Bad Girl (1931), A Farewell to Arms (1932), Man's Castle (1933), History Is Made at Night (1937), The Mortal Storm (1940) and Moonrise (1948).

heading: Deaths
txt: Ed Wynn, American actor and comedian (b. 1886)

entities.title: Ed Wynn
entities.description: Isaiah Edwin Leopold, better known as Ed Wynn, was an American actor and comedian, noted for his Perfect Fool comedy character, his pioneering radio show of the 1930s, and his later career as a dramatic actor.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Joseph Sweeney, American bishop (b. 1898)

entities.title: James Joseph Sweeney
entities.description: James Joseph Sweeney was an American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. He was the first Bishop of Honolulu, serving from 1941 until his death in 1968.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sam Giancana, American mob boss (b. 1908)

entities.title: Sam Giancana
entities.description: Samuel Mooney Giancana was an American mobster who was boss of the Chicago Outfit from 1957 to 1966.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ali Shariati, Iranian sociologist and philosopher (b. 1933)

entities.title: Ali Shariati
entities.description: Ali Shariati Mazinani was an Iranian revolutionary and sociologist who focused on the sociology of religion. He is held as one of the most influential Iranian intellectuals of the 20th century and has been called the "ideologue of the Iranian Revolution", although his ideas ended up not forming the basis of the Islamic Republic.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Popenoe, American explorer and scholar, founded Relationship counseling (b. 1888)

entities.title: Paul Popenoe
entities.description: Paul Bowman Popenoe was an American agricultural explorer and eugenicist. He was an influential advocate of the compulsory sterilization of the mentally ill and the mentally disabled, and the father of marriage counseling in the United States.

entities.title: Relationship counseling
entities.description: Couples therapy attempts to improve romantic relationships and resolve interpersonal conflicts.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anya Phillips, Chinese-American band manager and co-founder of the Mudd Club (b. 1955)

entities.title: Anya Phillips
entities.description: Anya Phillips was an American fashion influencer and the co-founder of legendary New York nightclub the Mudd Club along with Steve Mass and Diego Cortez. Phillips had an influence on the fashion, sound and look of the New York-based no wave scene of the late 1970s. She was also the manager and girlfriend of New York-based musician James Chance.

entities.title: Mudd Club
entities.description: The Mudd Club was a nightclub in the TriBeCa neighborhood of Lower Manhattan in New York City, that operated from 1978 to 1983 as a venue for underground music and counterculture events. It was located at 77 White Street and was opened by Steve Mass, art curator Diego Cortez and downtown punk scene figure Anya Phillips.

Although there was much cross-pollination between their two styles, the relationship somewhat overshadowed her contribution for some time. heading: Deaths
txt: Len Bias, American basketball player (b. 1963)

entities.title: Len Bias
entities.description: Leonard Kevin Bias was an American college basketball player who attended the University of Maryland. During his four years playing for Maryland, he was named a first-team All-American. Two days after being selected by the Boston Celtics with the second overall pick in the 1986 NBA draft, Bias died from cardiac arrhythmia induced by a cocaine overdose.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Margaret Carver Leighton

heading: Deaths

entities.title: George Addes
entities.description: George F. Addes was a founder of the United Automobile Workers union and its secretary-treasurer from 1936 until 1947.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Golding, British novelist, playwright, and poet, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1911)

entities.title: William Golding
entities.description: Sir William Gerald Golding, was a British novelist, playwright, and poet. Best known for his debut novel Lord of the Flies (1954), he published another twelve volumes of fiction in his lifetime. In 1980, he was awarded the Booker Prize for Rites of Passage, the first novel in what became his sea trilogy, To the Ends of the Earth. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1983.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Townsend, Burmese-English captain and pilot (b. 1914)

entities.title: Peter Townsend (RAF officer)
entities.description: Group Captain Peter Wooldridge Townsend was a Burmese-born British Royal Air Force officer, flying ace, courtier and author. He was equerry to King George VI from 1944 to 1952 and held the same position for Queen Elizabeth II from 1952 to 1953. Townsend notably had a romance with Princess Margaret, the Queen's only sibling.

entities.title: Stanley Mosk
entities.description: Morey Stanley Mosk was an American jurist, politician, and attorney. He served as Associate Justice of the California Supreme Court for 37 years (1964–2001), the longest tenure in that court's history.

entities.title: Clayton Kirkpatrick
entities.description: Clayton Kirkpatrick was the editor of the Chicago Tribune newspaper from 1969 until 1979. He is credited with modernizing the Tribune, shifting its news coverage and editorial page away from reflexive partisanship and—in a famous editorial—calling for the resignation of President Richard Nixon in 1974.

entities.description: The prime minister of Hungary is the head of government in Hungary. The Prime Minister and the Cabinet are collectively accountable for their policies and actions to the Parliament, to their political party and ultimately to the electorate. The current holder of the office is Viktor Orbán, leader of the Fidesz – Hungarian Civic Alliance, who has served since 29 May 2010.

entities.description: The western lowland gorilla is one of two subspecies of the western gorilla that lives in montane, primary and secondary forest and lowland swampland in central Africa in Angola, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Equatorial Guinea and Gabon. ASL is a complete and organized visual language that is expressed by facial expression as well as movements and motions with the hands.
